data.url: 20003 ED Venous Thromboembolic Disease Prophylaxis in Lower Limb Injury 1.1.001.png

data.text: Contents

The purpose of this document is to outline the recommendations for the prescription of thromboprophylaxis for adult patients requiring lower limb immobilisation following injury, to reduce the risk of venous thromboembolism.
The guidance provides a structured, evidence-based flowchart for the prescription of anticoagulant medication to prevent VTE in patients with lower limb injury requiring temporary immobilisation.
It is not applicable to patients who are admitted to hospital as they will be assessed via the Trust venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk assessment and prophylaxis policy.

This guidance is for use in all patients aged 16 years and over presenting to the emergency department with a lower limb injury who are discharged home from the emergency department (ED) with temporary limb immobilisation.
It is the responsibility of the prescribing ED doctor or emergency nurse practitioner to follow the guideline in the prescription of thromboprophylaxis.
Subsequent application of the guideline will be by orthopaedics, thrombosis treatment team and haematology as required in the follow-up of these patients.
Includes:
Adult patients with:
Excludes:
Children
This guideline is an adaptation of the College of Emergency Medicine Guideline for the use of thromboprophylaxis in ambulatory trauma patients requiring temporary limb immobilisation.

The relationship between temporary limb immobilisation and DVT has been documented since 1944(1). This link persists despite modern medical care, with lower-limb immobilisation recently implicated as an aetiological factor in approximately 1.5 -3% of all VTE events (2, 3). DVT carries inherent risks of post-thrombotic syndrome and of pulmonary embolus caused by thrombus propagation.

The recent Cochrane review extracted data from six studies16–21 involving just under 3000 randomised patients; symptomatic VTE occurred in 1.8%– 5.5% of conservatively managed patients. These results suggest that without thromboprophylaxis, approximately 1 in every 50 patients will suffer a symptomatic VTE event (including symptomatic distal and proximal DVT and pulmonary embolism (PE)) following temporary immobilisation after injury. This is likely to be an underestimate given the exclusion of high-risk patients from trial design and the general health equity of patients willing to engage with research. Based on the mean costs and QALYs gained there is an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) for thromboprophylaxis compared with no thromboprophylaxis of £13524. Based on standard thresholds used by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) in England, this value would fall below the ICER threshold of £20000 and, as such, the intervention would broadly be considered as cost-effective (Horner et al EMJ 2020.)
When indicated, thromboprophylaxis reduces the incidence of VTE in ambulatory patients with lower limb immobilisation (odds ratio 0.45 95% CI

The risks of providing pharmacological thromboprophylaxis for patients without contraindications are minimal. Definitive trials stratifying patients by other associated risk of VTE and plaster cast are not available. Given the significant risk of DVT, the potential impact of VTE and the very low risk associated with prophylaxis, this guideline recommends the prescription of VTE prophylaxis to all adult patients requiring lower limb immobilisation unless they have an individual contraindication (e.g. allergy).

Once commenced, thromboprophylaxis should be continued for the duration of the immobilisation, unless the patient is scheduled for surgery in which case it should be stopped 24 hours prior to the procedure.

For the subgroup of patients with tendo-achilles rupture, who are at higher risk of VTE, prophylaxis should be offered. The ‘consider' recommendation is a reflection of the very low to moderate quality evidence.
Patients identified as having thrombosis risk present and no bleeding risk should be prescribed prophylaxis as outlined below.

Blood tests are not required for all patients. Request blood tests (FBC, coagulation and renal function) for patients with a known history or a suspicion of a bleeding disorder or known renal disease.
Discuss the risks of VTE and provide a patient information leaflet: Prevention of deep vein thrombosis in lower limb immobilisation.
Instruct patients to return urgently to the ED if they are developing symptoms of compartment syndrome or tight POP (increasing limb pain, dusky or pale toes) or develop bleeding.
Prescribe thromboprophylaxis from the point of immobilisation and to be continued for the duration of lower limb immobilisation (most commonly six weeks).
Lower limb immobilisation means the application of a plaster cast or splint to any part of the lower limb and non-weight bearing status.

data.text: Clinical Guideline Lead Emergency Medicine – To ensure guideline is up to date and available.
It is the responsibility of the prescribing ED clinician to follow the guideline in the prescribing of thromboprophylaxis.
The ED Senior team is responsible for ensuring that staff are familiar with and adhere to this policy and are responsible for monitoring its implementation.
Follow-up care is provided by orthopaedics and haematology as required.

All employees have an individual responsibility and accountability for the provision of safe and competent practice and are expected to adhere to Trust policies and follow the guidelines to prevent risks to themselves and others.
Consider thromboprophylaxis in all patients >16 years of age who are discharged with immobilisation of the lower limb in an above or below knee cast or splint and who are non-weight-bearing.
Assess for contraindications to VTE prophylaxis with LMWH:
Known bleeding risk or other coagulopathy (e.g. platelets <75 x 10, haemophilia, acute liver failure).
Major trauma within six weeks.
Recent brain or spinal surgery or other major intraspinal or intracerebral abnormalities.
Concurrent use of anticoagulants (e.g. warfarin with INR >2).
Acute haemorrhagic stroke within six weeks.
Acute upper GI bleed, peptic ulcer disease or
oesophageal varices.
Uncontrolled hypertension (230/120 mmHg or higher).
Enoxaparin subcutaneously x 6 weeks
Recommended enoxaparin doses:

table_items.text: Moderate risk/High Risk Normal BMI and Renal Function

data.text: *Having a fracture of the lower leg needing immobilisation generates a moderate risk by itself.
High-risk patients include:
Persons older than 60 years.
Patients  aged  40-60  years  who  have  additional  risk factors,  such  as  previous  VTE,  malignancy,  or hypercoagulability. (Refer to Appendix 1)
For high risk patients at extremes of body weight or with renal impairment (CrCl<30mls/min), refer to Appendix
The risk of calf DVT is estimated at 20-40% in this group, with clinical pulmonary embolism occurring in 2-4%.
If CrCl <30ml/min (or creatinine > 400umol/l) or patient is on renal dialysis prescribe 20mg irrespective of risk rating.
Pharmacy opening times:
Outpatient Pharmacy (A103): Monday – Friday: 9am – 5pm Saturday – Sunday: closed Inpatient Pharmacy (A105):
Monday – Friday: 8am – 6pm
Saturday, Sunday, Bank Holidays: 10am – 4pm
During opening hours, send the patient with the prescription to the outpatient pharmacy (A103).

When the outpatient pharmacy is closed, patients may leave their prescription in the post-box outside the pharmacy and collect the following day when opening hours allow (i.e. drop off on Sunday – Thursday).

Where the outpatient pharmacy is closed and it is not possible to collect the prescription the following day, send the prescription to the inpatient pharmacy if open or contact the emergency floor pharmacist (when available) or on call pharmacist if urgent.
In all cases, the patient MUST receive a stat dose of VTE prophylaxis before leaving the department if they are unable to collect their prescription that day.
ED Team will prescribe the treatment for the first 14 days and this will be reviewed and continued by the Orthopaedic team if deemed appropriate (See appendix 4)
If NO follow up planned but VTE prophylaxis still indicated then the ED Team will prescribe for 6 weeks.
Compliance with the key standards set out in this document will be monitored by audit against the following key criteria:
Thromboprophylaxis is to be prescribed in accordance with the standards set out in this document.
A thromboprophylaxis patient information leaflet is to be provided to each relevant patient.
The guidance will be audited in accordance with the Trust and the Royal College of Emergency Medicine standards by the ED Consultant responsible for audit.
The same consultant will be responsible for reviewing the results and feedback recommendations for modifications to the guidance.
The audit will take place one year after implementation.

Any identified adverse events pertaining to the prescription or non- prescription of thromboprophylaxis (e.g. DVT, bleeding, adverse drug reaction) are to be documented and will be collated by the ED consultant responsible for clinical governance and discussed at the emergency department morbidity and mortality meeting.
This document will be reviewed and modified by the authors as required in response to audit, adverse events or other concerns raised.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 3)

Appendix 1: Risk Assessment Flow Chart

table_items.text: Patient Over 16yrs with Acute Severe Injury (Dislocation, Fracture or Complete Tendon Rupture)
Treated in a Cast, Splint OR Boot
A: Unable to fully weight bare* (e.g. NWB in cast or PWB only in cast or boot with touching toes and dependent on crutches.)
Acquired bleeding disorders (such as acute liver failure)
*If A is the ONLY additional risk factor then counsel and offer Enoxaparin 20 mg SC OD for duration of immobilisation OR until fully weight bearing in a splint or boot
anticoagulants known to increase the risk of bleeding (such as warfarin with INR >2)
Thrombocytopenia (platelets< 75x109/l) or previous HIT (Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia)
One or more significant medical comorbidities: cardiac failure / COPD / chronic renal failure or inflammatory bowel disease
Uncontrolled systolic hypertension (230/120 mmHg or higher)
Untreated inherited bleeding disorders (such as haemophilia and von Willebrand's disease)
-degree relative with a history of VTE
**Counsel Patient and Offer: Enoxaparin subcutaneously x 6 weeks. (See Appendix 2)
Discuss with ED Senior or Haematology if concerned regarding VTE and high bleeding risk
Pharmacological prophylaxis indicated If eGFR <30mls/min prescribe 20mg Enoxaparin

data.text: **Please see guidelines on counselling advice with evidence below in Appendix
Appendix 2- Enoxaparin Prescribing
Table to show recommended doses of enoxaparin for thromboprophylaxis in medical and surgical patients (excluding maternity and paediatric patients)

table_items.text: 20mg OD or discuss with haematology depending on individual patient risk factors.

data.text: Appendix 3- Clinical Studies

Risk of symptomatic VTE (DVT and PE) is between 1.8 and 5.5% for all comers (roughly 1 in 50 to 1 in 18 people.) For people in the higher risk groups e.g. over 60 with history of active cancer or previous history of VTE it is between  – 40% (1 in 5 to 2 in 5.)

Reduction in risk of VTE using prophylaxis is to approximately 1% but not to 0% so it must be made clear to the patients that VTE can still occur despite prophylaxis. All patients with immobilisation of the lower limb including those fully weight bearing in a boot or splint must be given a VTE leaflet on discharge which explains the signs and symptoms of VTE.

Fatal PE rate is very rare at approximately  per 100,000 for patients with lower limb immobilisation. This is approximately halved by prophylaxis to 7 per 100,000 however the benefit is offset by the increase in fatal and major bleeding events. The main benefits of VTE prophylaxis are the approximately 50% reductions in symptomatic PE, DVT, asymptomatic DVT, post thrombotic syndrome (the major benefit) and chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension halving the associated future morbidity for immobilised patients and cost for the healthcare service.
Patients should be counselled along these lines and given an informed choice as to whether to accept prophylaxis. This discussion and their decision should be recorded in the notes.
